title: Deliver a Project Pitch Presentation
short_name: Present your project idea with slides
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students create a 3-4 minute presentation with slides explaining their project idea, what problem it solves, and why it matters. They practice delivery with a partner, receive structured feedback on clarity and engagement, and revise their pitch based on suggestions. Students learn to communicate technical ideas to non-technical audiences.

title: Write User Stories for Your App
short_name: Create user stories to guide features
description: Students write 5-10 user stories using the format 'As a [user type], I want [feature] so that [benefit]' to capture what their app should do and why. They then prioritize stories into must-have versus nice-to-have categories, learning to focus on core functionality. This structured approach helps students translate user needs into concrete features.

title: Create Wireframes for Key App Screens
description: Students sketch or use digital tools to create simple wireframes (low-fidelity mockups) for 3-5 key screens of their app, showing layout, buttons, text areas, and navigation flow. Wireframes focus on structure and functionality rather than visual design, helping students plan before coding. They annotate wireframes with notes about what each element does.

title: Create an App Concept Proposal
description: Students write a 1-2 page proposal including: problem statement (what problem exists and who experiences it), target users (age, context, needs), proposed solution overview (how the app addresses the problem), and 3-5 key features (specific functionality with success criteria for each). This structured planning helps students think through their entire project before coding begins.

title: Research and Compare Existing Solutions
description: Students research 3-5 existing apps or solutions that address similar problems to their project idea. For each, they document what it does well, what it does poorly, what features it has, and who it serves. Then they identify gaps or unmet needs their app could address, helping differentiate their solution. This competitive analysis strengthens their project proposal.

title: Conduct Beta Testing with Target Users
description: Students recruit 3-5 target users (matching their app's intended audience), have them test the app while completing structured tasks, collect feedback using a testing form (what worked, what confused them, what broke), document all bugs and suggestions in an organized list, and create a prioritized action plan for fixes. This teaches systematic user testing and iteration.

title: Create a Simple App Demo Video
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students create a 1-2 minute video using screen recording with narration showing: (1) the problem their app solves, (2) demonstration of 3-4 key features in action, (3) explanation of why this helps users. The focus is on clarity and completeness rather than production quality. Students learn to demonstrate their work effectively for competitions and showcases.

title: Create and Deliver an Elevator Pitch
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students write and practice a 60-90 second verbal pitch delivered with no slides or props. The pitch includes: compelling problem hook (grab attention), solution explanation (what the app does), why it matters (impact statement), and memorable closing. Students practice until delivery is smooth, confident, and stays within time limit. This prepares them for science fairs and pitch competitions.

title: Design High-Fidelity UI Mockups
description: Students create detailed, styled mockups for 3-5 screens with specific colors, fonts, icons, button styles, and precise layouts. Using design tools (Figma, Canva, or CreatiCode's design features), they show what the final app will look like before implementing it. Mockups include visual hierarchy, consistent styling, and accessibility considerations like color contrast and readable font sizes.

title: Document Technical Architecture
description: Students create a technical architecture document showing: (1) technology stack and tools used (CreatiCode, which APIs, data storage method), (2) major components with descriptions (sprites and their roles, data structures, custom functions), (3) data flow diagram showing how information moves through the app (user input → processing → output/display). This helps explain technical decisions and system design.

title: Define Functional Requirements from User Stories
description: Students translate their user stories into specific functional requirements using precise language: 'The app must...', 'Users can...', 'When [action] happens, the system will...'. For each requirement, they define clear success criteria (how to verify it works correctly). This bridges user needs and technical implementation, making features testable and concrete.

title: Deploy Your App to the Web
description: Students deploy their CreatiCode app to a public URL using CreatiCode's sharing platform or similar web hosting. They verify the app works correctly when accessed from different devices (laptop, tablet, phone) and browsers, test all features in the deployed version, and share the link with beta testers for remote testing. This teaches the deployment and distribution process.

title: Write a Competition-Ready App Proposal
description: Students write a comprehensive 2-3 page proposal meeting competition requirements: compelling problem statement with data and evidence (statistics, research, interviews), detailed target audience description (demographics, context, specific needs), comprehensive solution with technical approach (architecture, key algorithms, data flow), expected impact with measurable outcomes, and realistic implementation timeline. This demonstrates professional project planning.

title: Conduct Competitive Analysis for Your App
description: Students research 3-5 competitor apps in depth, creating a detailed comparison table showing features, strengths, weaknesses, pricing/access models, and target users. They analyze market positioning, identify differentiation opportunities, and articulate how their app is unique or better (features competitors lack, better user experience, serving underserved populations). This competitive analysis strengthens business planning for competitions.

title: Run a Comprehensive Beta Testing Program
description: Students recruit 10+ diverse beta testers representing different user groups, conduct multiple rounds of testing with different task scenarios for each round, collect both quantitative data (task completion rates, time to complete, error counts) and qualitative feedback (confusion points, feature requests, usability issues), analyze patterns across testers to identify systemic problems versus individual preferences, and create a detailed improvement roadmap prioritizing fixes by impact and effort.

title: Produce a Competition Demo Video
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students create a polished 1-3 minute demo video meeting competition standards: professional introduction with project name and team, clear problem-solution narrative arc, demonstration of 3-5 key features with smooth screen recording and clear voiceover explanation, impact statement with concrete benefits, and compelling call-to-action. They edit for pacing, remove awkward pauses, add transitions, and ensure audio quality. This demonstrates professional communication skills.

title: Pitch Your App to Judges
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students prepare and deliver a 5-minute competition-style pitch including: compelling opening hook that grabs attention, clear problem statement with supporting evidence, live or video solution demonstration highlighting innovation, impact measurement showing how success will be evaluated, and Q&A preparation with anticipated tough questions (scalability, competition, technical challenges). They practice handling questions confidently and presenting under pressure with time limits.

title: Prototype Interactive App Navigation
description: Students create an interactive prototype (clickable mockup) demonstrating how users navigate between screens, what happens when buttons are clicked, how forms and inputs behave, and how data flows through the interface. Using prototyping features in design tools (Figma, Adobe XD) or building working navigation in CreatiCode, they simulate the user experience before full implementation. This allows testing navigation and flow before coding all features.

title: Create a Technical Specification Document
description: Students create comprehensive technical documentation including: system architecture diagram showing components and relationships, technologies and APIs used with versions and justifications, data models documenting all list structures and variables with types and purposes, algorithms described with pseudocode for complex logic, security considerations (input validation, data privacy, authentication), and scalability notes (how the system handles growth). Suitable for technical review by judges or developers.

title: Publish Your App to an App Store or Platform
description: Students complete the full app publishing process: prepare app metadata (compelling name, clear description, screenshots showing key features, appropriate category tags), create privacy policy document explaining data collection and usage, submit to platform (CreatiCode gallery, web hosting service, or mobile app platform), navigate the review process addressing any feedback, and share the final public URL. They learn the real-world process of making apps publicly accessible.
